elements.content: Two-dimensional (2-D) cyano-bridged Cu–W bimetallic assemblies that include halogen-substituted pyridine molecules, [CuII(3-iodopyridine)4][CuII(3-iodopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (1) (triclinic crystal structure, P1̅ space group), [CuII(3-bromopyridine)4][CuII(3-bromopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (2) (triclinic, P1̅), and [CuII(3-chloropyridine)2(H2O)2][CuII(3-chloropyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2·4H2O (3) (monoclinic, P21/c), were synthesized. Thermogravimetric measurements demonstrate that 1 and 2 have high thermal durability up to ca. 150 °C (423 K) due to the lack of water molecules in the crystal and the stacked Cu–W 2-D layers with halogen bonding between halogen-substituted pyridine and the cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate. In contrast, 3 exhibits weight loss above ca. 50 °C (323 K) as the water molecules between the 2-D layers are removed upon heating. Magnetic measurements show that 1–3 are ferromagnets due to parallel ordering of the magnetic spins on CuII (S = 1/2) and WV (S = 1/2) with Curie temperatures (T C) of 4.7 K (1), 5.2 K (2), and 7.2 K (3).
elements.clean_text: Two-dimensional (2-D) cyano-bridged Cu-W bimetallic assemblies that include halogen-substituted pyridine molecules, [CuII(3-iodopyridine)4][CuII(3-iodopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (1) (triclinic crystal structure, P1̅ space group), [CuII(3-bromopyridine)4][CuII(3-bromopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (2) (triclinic, P1̅), and [CuII(3-chloropyridine)2(H2O)2][CuII(3-chloropyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2⋅4H2O (3) (monoclinic, P21/c), were synthesized. Thermogravimetric measurements demonstrate that 1 and 2 have high thermal durability up to ca. 150 °C (423 K) due to the lack of water molecules in the crystal and the stacked Cu-W 2-D layers with halogen bonding between halogen-substituted pyridine and the cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate. In contrast, 3 exhibits weight loss above ca. 50 °C (323 K) as the water molecules between the 2-D layers are removed upon heating. Magnetic measurements show that 1-3 are ferromagnets due to parallel ordering of the magnetic spins on CuII (S = 1/2) and WV (S = 1/2) with Curie temperatures (T C) of 4.7 K (1), 5.2 K (2), and 7.2 K (3).

elements.content: Two-dimensional (2-D) cyano-bridged Cu−W bimetallic ferromagnets that include halogen-substituted pyridine molecules were synthesized. The 2-D layers are stacked through the halogen bonding between halogen-substituted pyridine ligand and cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate, and the durability up to 150 °C (423 K) is because the crystal structure lacks water molecules.
elements.clean_text: Two-dimensional (2-D) cyano-bridged Cu-W bimetallic ferromagnets that include halogen-substituted pyridine molecules were synthesized. The 2-D layers are stacked through the halogen bonding between halogen-substituted pyridine ligand and cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate, and the durability up to 150 °C (423 K) is because the crystal structure lacks water molecules.

elements.content: In recent years, cyano-bridged bimetallic assemblies have been aggressively synthesized, and particularly, their physical properties have been studied. For example, octacyanometalate [M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W, and Nb)-based bimetallic assemblies with various dimensional crystal structures (zero-dimensional (0-D), 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) have been synthesized, and numerous attractive magnetic functionalities such as photomagnetism, gas adsorption-induced magnetism, nonlinear magneto optical effect, and spin crossover ferromagnetism, have been reported. However, one drawback of [M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W, and Nb)-based magnets is a low thermal stability. Typically, cyano-bridged bimetallic assemblies contain water molecules as coordinating ligands and/or zeolitic molecules in the interstitial sites, and these water molecules are eliminated from the lattice upon warming. One approach to avoid this issue is to synthesize a water-free cyano-bridged bimetallic assembly.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, cyano-bridged bimetallic assemblies have been aggressively synthesized, and particularly, their physical properties have been studied. For example, octacyanometalate [M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W, and Nb)-based bimetallic assemblies with various dimensional crystal structures (zero-dimensional (0-D), 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) have been synthesized, and numerous attractive magnetic functionalities such as photomagnetism, gas adsorption-induced magnetism, nonlinear magneto optical effect, and spin crossover ferromagnetism, have been reported. However, one drawback of [M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W, and Nb)-based magnets is a low thermal stability. Typically, cyano-bridged bimetallic assemblies contain water molecules as coordinating ligands and/or zeolitic molecules in the interstitial sites, and these water molecules are eliminated from the lattice upon warming. One approach to avoid this issue is to synthesize a water-free cyano-bridged bimetallic assembly.

elements.content: Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structures, thermogravimetric analysis, and magnetic properties of [CuII(3-iodopyridine)4][CuII(3-iodopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (1), [CuII(3-bromopyridine)4][CuII(3-bromopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (2), and [CuII(3-chloropyridine)2(H2O)2][CuII(3-chloropyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2·4H2O (3). Compounds 1–3 are ferromagnetic 2-D cyano-bridged Cu–W bimetallic assemblies that include halogen-substituted pyridines. Compounds 1 and 2 are water-free compounds with isomorphic structures and exhibit high thermal durability. In contrast, 3 contains ligand and zeolitic water molecules, and is not as thermally stable. The appearance of water-free crystal structures in 1 and 2 is related to the halogen-bonding force between the halogen-substituted pyridine ligand and the cyano nitrogen of [W(CN)8].
elements.clean_text: Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structures, thermogravimetric analysis, and magnetic properties of [CuII(3-iodopyridine)4][CuII(3-iodopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (1), [CuII(3-bromopyridine)4][CuII(3-bromopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (2), and [CuII(3-chloropyridine)2(H2O)2][CuII(3-chloropyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2⋅4H2O (3). Compounds 1-3 are ferromagnetic 2-D cyano-bridged Cu-W bimetallic assemblies that include halogen-substituted pyridines. Compounds 1 and 2 are water-free compounds with isomorphic structures and exhibit high thermal durability. In contrast, 3 contains ligand and zeolitic water molecules, and is not as thermally stable. The appearance of water-free crystal structures in 1 and 2 is related to the halogen-bonding force between the halogen-substituted pyridine ligand and the cyano nitrogen of [W(CN)8].

elements.content: A green block-type single crystal of 1 was prepared by slow diffusion of a mixed aqueous solution of CuCl2·2H2O (6.0 × 10–3 mol dm–3) and 3-iodopyridine (6.0 × 10–3 mol dm–3) into an aqueous solution of Cs3[W(CN)8]·2H2O (4.0 × 10–3 mol dm–3) at room temperature for one day. Calculated: Cu, 7.29%; W, 14.06%; C, 25.73%; H, 1.23%; N, 12.86%. Found: Cu, 7.13%; W, 13.91%; C, 25.44%; H, 1.43%; N, 12.71%. The infrared (IR) spectrum exhibited CN stretching peaks at 2192, 2185, and 2148 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

[CuII(3-iodopyridine)4][CuII(3-iodopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (1)

A green block-type single crystal of 1 was prepared by slow diffusion of a mixed aqueous solution of CuCl2⋅2H2O (6.0 × 10-3 mol dm-3) and 3-iodopyridine (6.0 × 10-3 mol dm-3) into an aqueous solution of Cs3[W(CN)8]⋅2H2O (4.0 × 10-3 mol dm-3) at room temperature for one day. Calculated: Cu, 7.29%; W, 14.06%; C, 25.73%; H, 1.23%; N, 12.86%. Found: Cu, 7.13%; W, 13.91%; C, 25.44%; H, 1.43%; N, 12.71%. The infrared (IR) spectrum exhibited CN stretching peaks at 2192, 2185, and 2148 cm-1.

elements.content: A green plate-type single crystal of 2 was prepared by slow diffusion of a mixed aqueous solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1.2 × 10–2 mol dm–3) and 3-bromopyridine (1.4 × 10–2 mol dm–3) into an aqueous solution of Cs3[W(CN)8]·2H2O (8.0 × 10–3 mol dm–3) at room temperature for five days. Calculated: Cu, 8.52%; W, 16.42%; C, 30.04%; H, 1.44%; N, 15.02%. Found: Cu, 8.41%; W, 16.67%; C, 29.88%; H, 1.62%; N, 15.05%. The IR spectrum displayed CN stretching peaks at 2191, 2181, and 2137 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
[CuII(3-bromopyridine)4][CuII(3-bromopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (2)

A green plate-type single crystal of 2 was prepared by slow diffusion of a mixed aqueous solution of CuCl2⋅2H2O (1.2 × 10-2 mol dm-3) and 3-bromopyridine (1.4 × 10-2 mol dm-3) into an aqueous solution of Cs3[W(CN)8]⋅2H2O (8.0 × 10-3 mol dm-3) at room temperature for five days. Calculated: Cu, 8.52%; W, 16.42%; C, 30.04%; H, 1.44%; N, 15.02%. Found: Cu, 8.41%; W, 16.67%; C, 29.88%; H, 1.62%; N, 15.05%. The IR spectrum displayed CN stretching peaks at 2191, 2181, and 2137 cm-1.

elements.content: A light green plate-type single crystal of 3 was prepared by slow diffusion of a mixed aqueous solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1.2 × 10–2 mol dm–3) and 3-chloropyridine (1.4 × 10–2 mol dm–3) into an aqueous solution of Cs3[W(CN)8]·2H2O (8.0 × 10–3 mol dm–3) at room temperature for five days. Calculated: Cu, 10.81%; W, 20.84%; C, 31.32%; H, 2.06%; N, 17.47%. Found: Cu, 10.82%; W, 21.29%; C, 31.28%; H, 2.11%; N, 17.51%. The IR spectrum had CN stretching peaks at 2188 and 2155 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
[CuII(3-chloropyridine)2(H2O)2][CuII(3-chloropyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2⋅4H2O (3)

A light green plate-type single crystal of 3 was prepared by slow diffusion of a mixed aqueous solution of CuCl2⋅2H2O (1.2 × 10-2 mol dm-3) and 3-chloropyridine (1.4 × 10-2 mol dm-3) into an aqueous solution of Cs3[W(CN)8]⋅2H2O (8.0 × 10-3 mol dm-3) at room temperature for five days. Calculated: Cu, 10.81%; W, 20.84%; C, 31.32%; H, 2.06%; N, 17.47%. Found: Cu, 10.82%; W, 21.29%; C, 31.28%; H, 2.11%; N, 17.51%. The IR spectrum had CN stretching peaks at 2188 and 2155 cm-1.

elements.content: Elemental analyses of Cu and W for the prepared crystals were measured by HP4500 inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS), while those of C, H, and N were determined by standard microanalytical methods. IR spectra were recorded on a JASCO FTIR-4100 spectrometer in the 4000–400 cm–1 region. Thermogravimetric measurements were conducted by RIGAKU Thermo Plus TG8120 at a heating rate of 2 °C min–1. Magnetic measurements were carried out by a quantum design MPMS-5 superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Measurements

Elemental analyses of Cu and W for the prepared crystals were measured by HP4500 inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS), while those of C, H, and N were determined by standard microanalytical methods. IR spectra were recorded on a JASCO FTIR-4100 spectrometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric measurements were conducted by RIGAKU Thermo Plus TG8120 at a heating rate of 2 °C min-1. Magnetic measurements were carried out by a quantum design MPMS-5 superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer.

elements.content: For X-ray structural analyses, single crystals of 0.15 × 0.14 × 0.07 mm3 (1), 0.17 × 0.17 × 0.06 mm3 (2), and 0.30 × 0.09 × 0.06 mm3 (3) were mounted on Micro Mounts. All measurements were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo–Kα radiation. The crystal structures were solved by a direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-97. All calculations were performed using the Crystal Structure crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of 3-iodopyridine, 3-bromopyridine, and 3-chloropyridine were refined using the riding model.
elements.clean_text: For X-ray structural analyses, single crystals of 0.15 × 0.14 × 0.07 mm3 (1), 0.17 × 0.17 × 0.06 mm3 (2), and 0.30 × 0.09 × 0.06 mm3 (3) were mounted on Micro Mounts. All measurements were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation. The crystal structures were solved by a direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-97. All calculations were performed using the Crystal Structure crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of 3-iodopyridine, 3-bromopyridine, and 3-chloropyridine were refined using the riding model.

elements.content: X-ray single crystal structural analysis indicates 1 consists of a 2-D cyano-bridged network (triclinic, P1̅, a = 10.1924(3) Å, b = 11.7060(3) Å, c = 16.9698(4) Å, α = 80.3176(8)°, β = 82.9188(8)°, γ = 64.7791(7)°, and Z = 1) (Table ) (). The asymmetric unit is composed of one-half of [Cu1(3-iodopyridine)4]2+ ion, one [Cu2(3-iodopyridine)2]2+ ion, and one [W(CN)8]3– ion. The coordination geometry around W is an eight-coordinated bicapped trigonal prism where four cyano ligands are coordinated to one Cu1 and three Cu2, and the other four cyano ligands are free (Figure a). The coordination geometry around Cu1 is a six-coordinated pseudo-octahedron in which Cu1 is coordinated to four nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyrodine and two nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The coordination geometry around Cu2 is a five-coordinated square pyramid in which Cu2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyridine and three nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The average distance between Cu–W via a CN bridge inside of 2-D layer is 5.44 Å (Cu1-N1-C1-W1, 5.709 Å; Cu2-N3-C3-W1, 5.317 Å; Cu2-N4-C4-W1, 5.442 Å; and Cu2-N8-C8-W1, 5.304 Å). The 2-D Cu1-W-Cu2 layers in the ac plane are stacked along the b-axis (Figure b and c). It is important to note that the crystal structure does not contain water molecules. The distance between the iodine atom of 3-iodopyridine and the nitrogen atom in the cyano ligand (3.09 Å; I(2)···N(5)) is shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.53 Å estimated from 1.98 Å of the I atom and 1.55 Å of the N atom). The angle of C–I···N is ∠C(15)I(2)N(5) = 169.7°.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

X-ray single crystal structural analysis indicates 1 consists of a 2-D cyano-bridged network (triclinic, P1̅, a = 10.1924(3) Å, b = 11.7060(3) Å, c = 16.9698(4) Å, α = 80.3176(8)°, β = 82.9188(8)°, γ = 64.7791(7)°, and Z = 1) (Table ) (). The asymmetric unit is composed of one-half of [Cu1(3-iodopyridine)4]2+ ion, one [Cu2(3-iodopyridine)2]2+ ion, and one [W(CN)8]3- ion. The coordination geometry around W is an eight-coordinated bicapped trigonal prism where four cyano ligands are coordinated to one Cu1 and three Cu2, and the other four cyano ligands are free (Figure a). The coordination geometry around Cu1 is a six-coordinated pseudo-octahedron in which Cu1 is coordinated to four nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyrodine and two nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The coordination geometry around Cu2 is a five-coordinated square pyramid in which Cu2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyridine and three nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The average distance between Cu-W via a CN bridge inside of 2-D layer is 5.44 Å (Cu1-N1-C1-W1, 5.709 Å; Cu2-N3-C3-W1, 5.317 Å; Cu2-N4-C4-W1, 5.442 Å; and Cu2-N8-C8-W1, 5.304 Å). The 2-D Cu1-W-Cu2 layers in the ac plane are stacked along the b-axis (Figure b and c). It is important to note that the crystal structure does not contain water molecules. The distance between the iodine atom of 3-iodopyridine and the nitrogen atom in the cyano ligand (3.09 Å; I(2)⋅⋅⋅N(5)) is shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.53 Å estimated from 1.98 Å of the I atom and 1.55 Å of the N atom). The angle of C-I⋅⋅⋅N is ∠C(15)I(2)N(5) = 169.7°.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 is the same as that of 1 (triclinic, P1̅, a = 10.1695(3) Å, b = 11.7943(3) Å, c = 16. 2736(4) Å, α = 81.6600(7)°, β = 82.6040(8)°, γ = 64.6160(7)°, and Z = 1) (Figure and Table ). elements.content: In 1 and 2, the distance of I(2)···N(5) (or Br(2)···N(5)) is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of I (or Br) and N, suggesting that halogen bonds exist between iodopyridine (or bromopyridine) and the cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate. The I···N distance is reported to be between 2.72 Å and 3.25 Å, and the ∠C–I–N angle ranges from 165° to 177° in [Cr(CN)6]3– complexes with iodine-substituted TTF derivatives. On the basis of this knowledge, the I(2)···N(5) distance of 3.09 Å and the ∠C(15)I(2)N(5) angle of 169.7° in 1 suggest the existence of halogen bonds. Similarly, the formation of halogen bonds between bromopyridine and the cyano ligand is confirmed in 2.
elements.clean_text:
Halogen Bonds

In 1 and 2, the distance of I(2)⋅⋅⋅N(5) (or Br(2)⋅⋅⋅N(5)) is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of I (or Br) and N, suggesting that halogen bonds exist between iodopyridine (or bromopyridine) and the cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate. The I⋅⋅⋅N distance is reported to be between 2.72 Å and 3.25 Å, and the ∠C-I-N angle ranges from 165° to 177° in [Cr(CN)6]3- complexes with iodine-substituted TTF derivatives. On the basis of this knowledge, the I(2)⋅⋅⋅N(5) distance of 3.09 Å and the ∠C(15)I(2)N(5) angle of 169.7° in 1 suggest the existence of halogen bonds. Similarly, the formation of halogen bonds between bromopyridine and the cyano ligand is confirmed in 2.

elements.content: Furthermore, GAUSSIAN 09 is used for a molecular orbital calculation of the bond between the cyano nitrogen and 3-iodopyridine (or 3-bromopyridine). Figure shows the calculated molecular orbitals for I(2)···N(5) in 1 and Br(2)···N(5) in 2. The charge–density maps support the existence of covalency between I (or Br) and CN. In 1 and 2, halogen bonds between the 2-D layers inhibit the access of water molecules into the Cu ion. In contrast, 3 does not contain halogen bonds, which is likely because the electron deficiency on the halogen atom of 3-chloropyridine is weaker than that of 3-iodopyridine (or 3-bromopyridine). Because 3 contains ligand water and zeolitic molecules, it is not thermally durable.

elements.content: Compound 1 exhibits a spontaneous magnetization with a Curie temperature (T C) of 4.7 K as shown in the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) curve (Figure a). The zero-field-cooled magnetization (ZFCM) and remnant magnetization (RM) curves also support this T C. The magnetization vs external magnetic field curve at 2 K indicates a saturation magnetization (M s) value of 5.1 μB (Figure a, inset). Compound 2 shows magnetic properties similar to those of 1 with a T C value of 5.2 K and a M s value of 5.1 μB (Figure b, inset). In 3, the T C and M s values are 7.2 K and 5.0 μB, respectively (Figure c, inset). The observed M s values of 5.1 μB (1), 5.1 μB (2), and 5.0 μB (3) agree with the expected value of 5 μB for ferromagnetic coupling between CuII and WV, indicating that these compounds are ferromagnets. The order of the T C values (4.7 K (1), 5.2 K (2), and 7.5 K (3)) corresponds to the order for the average distance of Cu–W via a CN bridge inside the 2-D layer, 5.44 Å (1), 5.33 Å (2), and 5.32 Å (3). This relationship suggests that the T C values are attributed to the superexchange interactions between Cu and W in the 2-D layer.

Magnetic Properties

Compound 1 exhibits a spontaneous magnetization with a Curie temperature (T C) of 4.7 K as shown in the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) curve (Figure a). The zero-field-cooled magnetization (ZFCM) and remnant magnetization (RM) curves also support this T C. The magnetization vs external magnetic field curve at 2 K indicates a saturation magnetization (M s) value of 5.1 μB (Figure a, inset). Compound 2 shows magnetic properties similar to those of 1 with a T C value of 5.2 K and a M s value of 5.1 μB (Figure b, inset). In 3, the T C and M s values are 7.2 K and 5.0 μB, respectively (Figure c, inset). The observed M s values of 5.1 μB (1), 5.1 μB (2), and 5.0 μB (3) agree with the expected value of 5 μB for ferromagnetic coupling between CuII and WV, indicating that these compounds are ferromagnets. The order of the T C values (4.7 K (1), 5.2 K (2), and 7.5 K (3)) corresponds to the order for the average distance of Cu-W via a CN bridge inside the 2-D layer, 5.44 Å (1), 5.33 Å (2), and 5.32 Å (3). This relationship suggests that the T C values are attributed to the superexchange interactions between Cu and W in the 2-D layer.

elements.content: Three ferromagnetic 2-D cyano-bridged Cu–W bimetal assemblies containing halogen-substituted pyridine ligands, 1 (T C = 4.7 K), 2 (T C = 5.2 K), and 3 (T C = 7.2 K), have been synthesized. Because of the water-free structure provided by the halogen bonds between the halogen-substituted pyridine and cyano ligands, 1 and 2 show high thermal durability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three ferromagnetic 2-D cyano-bridged Cu-W bimetal assemblies containing halogen-substituted pyridine ligands, 1 (T C = 4.7 K), 2 (T C = 5.2 K), and 3 (T C = 7.2 K), have been synthesized. Because of the water-free structure provided by the halogen bonds between the halogen-substituted pyridine and cyano ligands, 1 and 2 show high thermal durability.

cln_elements.content:
Two-dimensional (2-D) cyano-bridged Cu–W bimetallic assemblies that include halogen-substituted pyridine molecules, [CuII(3-iodopyridine)4][CuII(3-iodopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (1) (triclinic crystal structure, P1̅ space group), [CuII(3-bromopyridine)4][CuII(3-bromopyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2 (2) (triclinic, P1̅), and [CuII(3-chloropyridine)2(H2O)2][CuII(3-chloropyridine)2]2[WV(CN)8]2·4H2O (3) (monoclinic, P21/c), were synthesized. Thermogravimetric measurements demonstrate that 1 and 2 have high thermal durability up to ca. 150 °C (423 K) due to the lack of water molecules in the crystal and the stacked Cu–W 2-D layers with halogen bonding between halogen-substituted pyridine and the cyano nitrogen of octacyanotungstate. In contrast, 3 exhibits weight loss above ca. 50 °C (323 K) as the water molecules between the 2-D layers are removed upon heating. Magnetic measurements show that 1–3 are ferromagnets due to parallel ordering of the magnetic spins on CuII (S = 1/2) and WV (S = 1/2) with Curie temperatures (T C) of 4.7 K (1), 5.2 K (2), and 7.2 K (3).

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structures

X-ray single crystal structural analysis indicates 1 consists of a 2-D cyano-bridged network (triclinic, P1̅, a = 10.1924(3) Å, b = 11.7060(3) Å, c = 16.9698(4) Å, α = 80.3176(8)°, β = 82.9188(8)°, γ = 64.7791(7)°, and Z = 1) (Table ) (). The asymmetric unit is composed of one-half of [Cu1(3-iodopyridine)4]2+ ion, one [Cu2(3-iodopyridine)2]2+ ion, and one [W(CN)8]3– ion. The coordination geometry around W is an eight-coordinated bicapped trigonal prism where four cyano ligands are coordinated to one Cu1 and three Cu2, and the other four cyano ligands are free (Figure a). The coordination geometry around Cu1 is a six-coordinated pseudo-octahedron in which Cu1 is coordinated to four nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyrodine and two nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The coordination geometry around Cu2 is a five-coordinated square pyramid in which Cu2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyridine and three nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The average distance between Cu–W via a CN bridge inside of 2-D layer is 5.44 Å (Cu1-N1-C1-W1, 5.709 Å; Cu2-N3-C3-W1, 5.317 Å; Cu2-N4-C4-W1, 5.442 Å; and Cu2-N8-C8-W1, 5.304 Å). The 2-D Cu1-W-Cu2 layers in the ac plane are stacked along the b-axis (Figure b and c). It is important to note that the crystal structure does not contain water molecules. The distance between the iodine atom of 3-iodopyridine and the nitrogen atom in the cyano ligand (3.09 Å; I(2)···N(5)) is shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.53 Å estimated from 1.98 Å of the I atom and 1.55 Å of the N atom). The angle of C–I···N is ∠C(15)I(2)N(5) = 169.7°.

Thermal Durability

Thermogravimetric measurements indicate 1 is stable up to 150 °C but then loses weight due to the removal of 3-iodopyridine from the compound (Figure a). Similarly, 2 endures up to 150 °C, but the weight loss above 150 °C corresponds to the loss of 3-bromopyridine (Figure b). However, 3, loses weight at 55 °C, which corresponds to the loss of water molecules (Figure c). After that, 3-chloropyridine molecules are eliminated.

The coordination geometry around Cu2 is a five-coordinated square pyramid in which Cu2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of 3-iodopyridine and three nitrogen atoms from the cyano groups. The average distance between Cu-W via a CN bridge inside of 2-D layer is 5.44 Å (Cu1-N1-C1-W1, 5.709 Å; Cu2-N3-C3-W1, 5.317 Å; Cu2-N4-C4-W1, 5.442 Å; and Cu2-N8-C8-W1, 5.304 Å). The 2-D Cu1-W-Cu2 layers in the ac plane are stacked along the b-axis (Figure b and c). It is important to note that the crystal structure does not contain water molecules. The distance between the iodine atom of 3-iodopyridine and the nitrogen atom in the cyano ligand (3.09 Å; I(2)⋅⋅⋅N(5)) is shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.53 Å estimated from 1.98 Å of the I atom and 1.55 Å of the N atom). The angle of C-I⋅⋅⋅N is ∠C(15)I(2)N(5) = 169.7°.

Thermal Durability

Thermogravimetric measurements indicate 1 is stable up to 150 °C but then loses weight due to the removal of 3-iodopyridine from the compound (Figure a). Similarly, 2 endures up to 150 °C, but the weight loss above 150 °C corresponds to the loss of 3-bromopyridine (Figure b). However, 3, loses weight at 55 °C, which corresponds to the loss of water molecules (Figure c). After that, 3-chloropyridine molecules are eliminated.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

decomposition temperature.condition: due to the lack of water molecules
